all_paragraphs: Functional programming is a coding paradigm in which we define what to do rather than performing actions. The idea is originally adopted from mathematics — we define the inputs that go into a function and the output that we expect from it.

Functional programming rarely depends on the state management — meaning when we pass the same arguments no matter how many times the output will be the same. It can be interpreted as the data is undergoing some transformations, which ultimately result in the desired output.

Though Python is not primarily a functional language, it supports functional programming relatively simple because everything in Python is an object. This means that function can be assigned to variables and passed around.
To keep things simple, let’s start with a simple function that prints Hello world. Have a look:

The syntax of the function starts with a def keyword followed by function name then circular braces. Defining functions ends with a colon(:). Then in the next line with four white-spaces indentation, the body of the function starts. Indentation is the most important thing we need to keep in mind while working with functions.

When we have a variable with the same name inside a function, and globally, there will be an ambiguity when we try to access that variable — whether we’re accessing the global variable or the function scoped variable.
So Python provided a function called globals() through which we can access global variables with the same names inside the functions. Have a look:
In Python, we can assign a function to a variable and then invoke it. Have a look:

Now that we know how to define a function, it’s time for the next phase, where we pass inputs to the functions — Arguments. To understand it quickly, we will start with a mathematical function where we calculate the sum of two numbers. Have a look:
It’s a simple function just like the first one, but with two inputs — a and b.
Functions with arguments can be invoked in two ways by merely calling the functions and passing the arguments in an order that mentioned in the functions or by using named arguments. Have a look:

In the above sample, a and b are two mandatory arguments — which means developers have to pass two arguments to invoke the function. In Python, we can specify arguments with default values. So those arguments will be optional parameters. While invoking the function if any of the optional argument is not passed then Python consider the default value of that argument. Have a look:

Python has the unique ability to return more than one value as the output, which most of the languages can’t do. Have a look:
x, y and z variables will be assigned with the values of plus, minus and multiplication, respectively.
Python functional programming has the ability to return a function as output or to pass it as an argument.

Until now, we’ve seen how to pass variables as arguments to functions. Now we will learn how to pass the function as an argument to other functions — Similar to higher-order functions in Kotlin. Have a look:

Lambda is the simplest form of a function with a single line expression, and it has no name. In Python, we have to use a lambda keyword instead of def to create a lambda function. Have a look:
Here variable f is a simple lambda function, whereas a and b are the arguments to f. The syntax is similar to normal function. The only change is the keyword and single-line expression.

Until now, we’ve seen how to create create a function and other tactics. Python out of the box contains default functions like map and filter, which comes handy in several use-cases.

map is a function that expects another function object and any number of iterables like list and dictionaries. map iterates every item in the list with the function object that was supplied to it and return a list. Have a look:
We can pass more than one list to map, as shown below:

filter function expects two arguments — a function object and an iterable. Filter iterates every item through the function object that returns a boolean value. Finally, the filter returns a list with the items that return true from the function object.
